title.narrative: Building a network of researchers with expertise in molecular diagnostics to monitor and investigate antimicrobial resistance (AMR) in South Asia

description.narrative: Building a network of researchers with expertise in molecular diagnostics to monitor and investigate antimicrobial resistance (AMR) in South Asia

The growing prevalence of AMR is a global health challenge that requires accurate and rapid diagnostic methods to confirm phenotypic testing in surveillance studies and to understand the mechanisms responsible for development of AMR. This project will create and deliver training programmes for researchers from Sri Lanka, Bangladesh and India to become expert in the detection of AMR, using techniques from basic antimicrobial susceptibility testing to molecular diagnostic methods. This objective will be achieved through an online training course followed by a practical workshop. The selection of researchers for training will be based on their current experience, future roles in AMR research with respect to diversity and gender balance. This training programme will create a network of researchers who are capable of conducting molecular AMR diagnostics safely and reliably to detect resistance-coding genes and/or resistance-associated mutations. The training programme will build on current and previous research partnerships and collaborations between the Royal Veterinary College and Anand Agricultural University (AAU), Gujarat, India. Appropriate ethical approvals will be confirmed prior to starting the training. The specific objectives are: 1. To develop an online training module in research skills in the diagnosis of antibacterial resistance. The training module will include basic phenotypic resistance testing and more advanced quantitative and molecular-based methods and their quality control. The online training course will be developed using appropriate pedagogical design and a variety of audio-visual media to include protocols for field collection and laboratory methods. Online training modules will be hosted on the iHEN (interdisciplinary Hub Education Network) Moodle-based platform which is specifically developed for the UKRI GCRF One Health Poultry HUB. 2. To offer practical workshops at AAU, Gujarat, India. The practical training will be provided to researchers that have satisfactorily completed the online training course. Practical training will include a) all necessary skills in obtaining and handling samples of faeces from animals and humans and samples of soil and water from the environment, b) growing pure culture c) phenotypic disc diffusion analysis of resistant isolates c) serotyping/phage typing, d) quantitative and molecular-based approaches including Polymerase chain reaction (PCR), quantitative PCR (qPCR), Next-generation Sequencing (NGS) and introducing whole genome sequencing and its uses for typing, generating phylogenetic trees, resistome analysis and identifying mutations related to AMR. 3. To fill a research skills gap in UKRI GCRF funded researchers and associated networks, including the One Health Poultry Hub
